Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Characterizing the Roles of Atmospheric Structure and Clouds on the Radiation and Precipitation Budgets at Summit, Greenland
Award.AbstractNarration:
Funds are provided to characterize the interactions among the atmospheric state, cloud properties, radiation, and precipitation at Summit, Greenland. The objective is to investigate a number of important cloud-related processes, how these interact with the Arctic climate system, and their impact on the surface energy and mass budgets. Specific foci will include:
1) Low-cloud persistence mechanisms that lead to long-lived Arctic stratiform clouds, which interact strongly with the atmospheric structure and surface energy budget;
2) Cloud-phase partitioning, which determines the cloud microphysical composition and, ultimately, the effects that clouds have on atmospheric radiation and the hydrologic cycle; and
3) Precipitation partitioning, in order to understand the different modes of precipitation at Summit and how these impact the total surface accumulation.
To address these topics, this project will utilize detailed observations from a suite of ground-based remote sensors deployed at Summit as part of the NSF/AON-funded ICECAPS project in combination with data from satellite-borne active remote sensors. High-resolution numerical modeling will also be used to investigate many of the fine-scale cloud processes and their mesoscale influences. These studies over the Greenland Ice Sheet will also be considered within the context of similar measurements and model studies made at other Arctic locations in order to understand these important processes over Summit and, in a more general sense, across the Arctic.

Atmospheric water vapor, clouds, and precipitation greatly affect the surface energy and cryospheric mass balances in the Arctic, and are responsible for much of the variability in these balances. It is thought that recent rapid melting of Arctic sea ice may be driven, in part, by changes in cloud cover and radiation. Cloud-related processes and feedbacks are known to be one of the greatest sources of uncertainty in global climate models, and these shortcomings have been clearly identified in model simulations over the Arctic. Thus, the results of this project should improve our understanding of Arctic cloud processes and their inclusion in climate models, which, in turn, will improve predictability.

As broader impacts of this research, the project will provide important data analysis and integration experience for four new graduate students at the participating universities. In addition, data and results from this study will be integrated into undergraduate coursework and summer workshops for high school students and teachers.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Anthropogenic climate change is currently accelerating melting of the Greenland Ice Sheet. This melting, in turn, contributes significantly to global sea level rise. To accurately predict how the Greenland Ice Sheet will respond to future climate change, a better understanding is needed of how both mass and energy are exchanged at the surface. This project uses observations from Summit Station in central Greenland to better understand how the atmosphere and clouds affect the surface mass and energy budgets of the Greenland Ice Sheet. This project uses observations made by the Integrated Characterization of Energy, Clouds Atmospheric state, and Precipitation at Summit (ICECAPS) field campaign, which has been operating continuously since 2010. The ICECAPS project has provided the first long-term data record of cloud and atmospheric properties over the central Greenland Ice Sheet. Analyses of these data have provided information on the roles that the near-surface temperature structure and different clouds play in modulating energy at the surface. ICECAPS observations have also been used to assess different precipitation patterns over the Greenland Ice Sheet, which is important for understanding the mass budget. Two distinct precipitation regimes exist over central Greenland that are associated with different large-scale weather patterns. These regimes highlight how the different weather systems affect both the type and intensity of precipitation over central Greenland. One of these regimes includes both water and ice clouds, while the other contains only ice clouds. The ICECAPS data are also being used to investigate the concentrations of atmospheric gases over the Greenland Ice Sheet, including ozone. These analyses are important for understanding how ozone is exchanged between the tropics and polar regions

Central Greenland, which is at high altitude (3200 m), is an endpoint of climate in the Arctic and, therefore, studies of this location represent some of the most extreme conditions in the Arctic. Summit Station also has historical significance because it is the drilling site of a deep ice core that was obtained in the 1990s. Thus, the data and analyses provided by this research project are very important for comparing to both regional and global models that predict future conditions of the Greenland Ice Sheet and of the entire Arctic. This project provided the first detailed analyses of processes that are important in central Greenland, where the ice sheet accumulates mass. However, the results obtained here are also important for scientists who study other portions of Greenland (coastal regions) and other processes such as melting and calving of ice. This project also supported graduate students at five universities: Washington State University, University of Wisconsin, University of Colorado, University of Oklahoma, and Vanderbilt University. The graduate students associated with this project gained valuable experience working with observational data and conducting scientific analyses. The project also supported summer research for undergraduates. Many of the students spent time in the field at Summit Station, which greatly enriched their educational experience and helped to provide the next generation of polar researchers.
